tools_reference.name: Drills
tools_reference.use: Mini electric drills are supplied with fine drill bits. They are more expensive than a hand-held pin vice but are quicker.

tools_reference.name: Mitre cutters
tools_reference.use: These are basically scissors for wood and will cut and mitre strip wood up to 1/2in thick. They are used as an alternative to a saw and mitre block.

tools_reference.name: Pin files
tools_reference.use: These have fine, shaped heads for intricate shaping and sanding.

tools_reference.name: Pin vice
tools_reference.use: A pin vice is used for drilling through wood and will hold extremely fine drill bits up to 1/8in diameter.

tools_reference.name: Right-angled gluing jig
tools_reference.use: A frame (easily made at home) with two fixed sides set at right angles which enables an object being glued to be held square.

tools_reference.name: Sandpaper
tools_reference.use: Essential for shaping, smoothing and distressing wood. Use fine-grade sandpaper for projects at this scale.

tools_reference.name: Saw and mitre block
tools_reference.use: A junior hacksaw or razor saw are used with a small mitre block to cut and mitre strip wood. They are used as an alternative to mitre cutters and will also cut brass tube.

diagram_descriptions: Several pieces of wood are shown, labeled Bass wood, Jelutong wood, Obechi wood, and Wood dowel.
A close-up of a saw and mitre block with a piece of wood being cut.
A pair of orange-handled mitre cutters.
A small metal pin vice with a fine point.
A right-angled gluing jig made of wood.
A piece of sandpaper.

tools_reference.name: 3-D gloss varnish
tools_reference.use: Produces a raised, glossy finish when dry. Often used as a rubber-stamping accessory.

tools_reference.name: Metallic pastes
tools_reference.use: Wax-based pastes, also known as gilt creams, can be applied sparingly to a painted surface to give the appearance of age and depth. Metallic shoe polish can be used as an alternative.

tools_reference.name: Paints
tools_reference.use: Available in a wide range, either water-based or oil-based. Water-based acrylic paints are recommended for most projects as they are non-toxic and easy to work with. Glass and enamel paints are also available in acrylics. Several of the projects require oil-based spray paints.

tools_reference.name: Paintbrushes
tools_reference.use: Artist's paintbrushes are available in a range of sizes ideal for painting miniatures.

tools_reference.name: Shoe polish
tools_reference.use: Used as a wax-based wood stain and polish, combined.

tools_reference.name: Steel wool
tools_reference.use: Use fine-grade wire to apply shoe polish to wood.

tools_reference.name: Superglue gel
tools_reference.use: This strong glue is useful as it bonds instantly.

tools_reference.name: Tacky glue
tools_reference.use: This non-toxic water-based glue dries clear, strong and flexible. It is particularly suited to wood, paper, card and fabric. Thick or mighty tacky glue is recommended for best results.

tools_reference.name: Wood stain
tools_reference.use: A water-based or oil-based colouring applied to wood with a soft cloth. Use water-based wood stains to achieve distressed paint effects.

tools_reference.name: Scissors
tools_reference.use: Small sharp scissors are essential for cutting paper and templates.

tools_reference.name: Paper punches
tools_reference.use: Several of the projects use paper punches, available in a wide variety of shapes and sizes for the craft worker.

tools_reference.name: Pliers
tools_reference.use: A useful tool for holding, cutting and bending wire.

tools_reference.name: Quilling tool
tools_reference.use: A small, hand-held tool used to coil quilling paper.

tools_reference.name: Wire cutters
tools_reference.use: A tool used specifically to cut wire.

tools_reference.name: Craft knife
tools_reference.use: An essential tool for cutting wood and card. Model-maker's knives with replaceable blades are preferable to Stanley knives. Always use with a cutting mat and steel ruler.

tools_reference.name: Cutting mat
tools_reference.use: This is a must when cutting with a craft knife, to protect working surfaces.

tools_reference.name: Ruler
tools_reference.use: A 12in steel ruler graduated in 1/16in is an essential basic tool.

tools_reference.name: Beads
tools_reference.use: A variety of beads are used in the projects. Specific details of the beads required are given for each project.

tools_reference.name: Belaying pins
tools_reference.use: A model ship-building component available in wood in various sizes from model shops.

tools_reference.name: Brass pins
tools_reference.use: Available in various sizes from miniature hardware specialists.

tools_reference.name: Brass sheet
tools_reference.use: Available from model shops. A cheaper alternative is the inside of a tomato purée tube.

tools_reference.name: Brass tube
tools_reference.use: A hollow tube available in a range of diameters from model shops and cut using a mitre block and junior hacksaw.

tools_reference.name: Bunka
tools_reference.use: Perhaps better known as lampshade fringing, this can be purchased either as fringing or tassels from haberdashery (notions) stores.

tools_reference.name: Canvas
tools_reference.use: Two types of needlework canvas are used in some projects - tapestry canvas and suit interlining canvas.

tools_reference.name: Centre cane
tools_reference.use: Used in basket making and available from specialist outlets in various thicknesses. It is known as round reed cane in the USA.

tools_reference.name: Clear plastic tube
tools_reference.use: Often used to cover the bristles on new artist's paintbrushes.

tools_reference.name: Cocktail sticks
tools_reference.use: A substitute for 1/16in hardwood dowel.

tools_reference.name: Cold porcelain
tools_reference.use: A non-toxic modelling material made from a mixture of PVA glue, cornflour and a preservative. It is most often used for cake decoration.

tools_reference.name: Double column
tools_reference.use: Model ship-building component, available in wood from most good model shops.

tools_reference.name: Eyelets
tools_reference.use: These are measured by the narrow opening at the top of the eyelet. Straight-ended ones are used in the projects rather than serrated ones.

tools_reference.name: Filigrees and findings
tools_reference.use: Metal egg-decorating components, including scrolls, spokes, frames, decorative caps and up-eyes have been used in some projects.

tools_reference.name: Floral tape
tools_reference.use: This is normally used to bind flowers and leaves together in cake decoration.

tools_reference.name: Flower shades
tools_reference.use: Plastic flower shades from egg decorating or jewellery suppliers.

tools_reference.name: Jewellery findings
tools_reference.use: These are metal jewellery-making components, including head pins, bead caps and pendant frames.

tools_reference.name: Paper balls
tools_reference.use: Compact-shaped paper balls used in various crafts.

tools_reference.name: Stamens
tools_reference.use: Used in the centre of a flower in cake decorating.

tools_reference.name: Water-slide transfers (decals)
tools_reference.use: Used to decorate a wide range of items. Separate the transfer from the paper backing by soaking in water for several minutes. Miniature transfers are often used in egg decorating.

tools_reference.name: Wire
tools_reference.use: Jewellery-making wire and florist's stub wire are available in various gauges. Some projects use paper-covered wire, which is commonly used in cake decoration.

tools_reference.name: Waxed thread
tools_reference.use: A thread treated with wax, often used in jewellery making.

tools_reference.name: Filigrees
tools_reference.use: Decorative metal elements.

tools_reference.name: Eyelets
tools_reference.use: Small metal rings used for reinforcement or decoration.

tools_reference.name: Colouring Mediums
tools_reference.use: Projects use various colouring mediums, including water-based acrylic paints, shoe polish and wood stain.

tools_reference.name: Paints
tools_reference.use: Apply acrylic water-based paints with an artist's paintbrush: medium (approx. size 6) and fine (approx. size 000) are needed for some projects. Several of the projects use oil-based spray or enamel paints; follow the manufacturer's safety instructions when using these products.

tools_reference.name: Shoe polish
tools_reference.use: Apply shoe polish to wood using fine-gauge wire wool and buff up to a sheen with clean wire wool or a cloth. Avoid using polish on edges to be glued, as the bond will not be as strong.

tools_reference.name: Wood stain
tools_reference.use: Apply wood stain to wood using a soft cloth and use sparingly as too much can warp the wood. Stain parts before assembly, allowing them to dry completely.

tools_reference.name: Distressing Techniques
tools_reference.use: A distressing technique is used to imitate age and wear and tear to a surface. Wood in particular responds well to such treatments. Make up the project following the instructions and paint with water-based acrylic paint. Sand the item in places where natural wear and tear would occur, to reveal the wood. Cover the whole article with a light water-based wood stain such as antique pine or medium oak. Remove the stain from the wood in accessible areas with a damp cloth. The stain will settle in the cracks and colour the bare wood, mimicking worn paint and grime. Use water-based wood stain and shoe polish sparingly to achieve aged finishes on other materials, such as paper, card and fabric.

tools_reference.name: Cutting Wood
tools_reference.use: Use a craft knife, mitre cutters or a saw to cut wood, cutting so the grain runs in line with the sides that have the longest measurement. Sand and polish wood following the grain.

tools_reference.name: Chamfering
tools_reference.use: This means creating an angle at the edge of the piece of wood. Hold the piece of wood upright (at a slight angle) above fine-grade sandpaper, with the edge to be chamfered facing down. Sand the edge in small sweeping motions in the same direction, until you achieve the correct angle. Two angles, 45 and 60 degrees, are drawn here.

tools_reference.name: Mitring
tools_reference.use: This means cutting the ends of two wood pieces to an angle of 45 degrees so they can be fitted together to make a right-angled joint. Use a mitre block and razor saw, positioning the saw in the slits of the mitre block to cut diagonally through the wood. Press the wood against the guide of the mitre cutters to achieve a 45-degree angle cut.

tools_reference.name: Framing
tools_reference.use: Mitring the ends of four strips of wood and then joining them together makes a frame. Each pair of pieces should be the same length. Position the corresponding size lengths opposite each other in a right-angled gluing jig (see page 8) and glue together. When mitring picture frame moulding, make sure the recess on the back of the wood runs with the shortest length of mitred wood strip.

tools_reference.name: Using Templates
tools_reference.use: Some of the projects have templates for you to use and these can be found on pages 61-62. Black and white templates should be photocopied for accuracy, although they may be traced with pencil and tracing paper if preferred. Colour templates should be reproduced either by colour photocopying on to white paper or card or by scanning the image into a computer and then printing on photo-quality card or paper.

A diorama scene depicting a medieval or Tudor-era setting. It features a dark wooden paneled wall as the backdrop. In the foreground, there is a rustic wooden throne-like chair, a small wooden stool with a dark mug on it, a tall candelabra with a white candle, and a polearm leaning against the wall. A large, broad-bladed axe is also leaning against the wall, positioned above the candle. The overall impression is one of historical or fantasy-themed miniature crafting.

projects.name: Wooden Stool

steps.instruction: Sand each of the wooden components using fine-grade sandpaper. Use steel wool to apply an oak-coloured shoe polish to colour and polish each of the wood pieces.
steps.visual_description: Image shows all the individual wooden pieces for the stool laid out flat, some are rectangular planks, others are smaller strips and blocks.

steps.instruction: Place two legs, a short seat support and a short leg support (positioned 1/16in from the end of each leg) in a right-angled gluing jig (see page 8) and glue together. Repeat the procedure with the remaining two legs and short supports.
steps.visual_description: Image shows two legs and two short supports being glued together in a right-angled jig, forming an 'H' shape.

steps.instruction: Once dry, take the leg constructions and place sideways in the gluing jig. Position and glue a long seat support and long leg support in between the leg structures and in line with the other supports. Repeat the procedure with the remaining wood pieces.
steps.visual_description: Image shows the two previously assembled leg structures being connected by long seat supports and long leg supports, forming the frame of the stool.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the frame centrally on to the underside of the seat. If you wish achieve the appearance of age and dirt on the polished surface, rub a small amount of black shoe polish into some areas and buff with wire wool.
steps.visual_description: Image shows the assembled stool frame being glued to the underside of the seat piece. The stool is shown from a top-down perspective.

tips: See Basic Techniques page 12 for more information on sanding and polishing.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature wooden stool with a rustic finish.

diagram_descriptions: A small, rustic wooden stool with four legs and a rectangular seat.
Diagram showing the individual wooden components for the stool laid out flat.
Diagram showing two legs and two short supports being glued together in a right-angled jig.
Diagram showing the assembled stool frame being connected by long seat supports and long leg supports.
Diagram showing the stool frame being glued to the underside of the seat.
A variation of the wooden stool, painted green, with a pierced finger hole in the seat.

projects.name: Torchère

steps.instruction: Place the aluminium plate upside-down and drill a hole centrally through the middle using a 3/64in drill bit. Cut the head end off the gold-plated head pin so it measures 1/8in. Keep the opposite end as this is used to make the prickett.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a circular aluminium plate with a hole in the center, and a gold-plated pin cut to size.

steps.instruction: Use superglue gel to secure the head pin into one end of the brass tube and the straight end of the pin (the prickett) into the opposite end. The prickett should protrude by 3/8in. Glue the scrolls on to the end of the brass tube, allowing each one to dry before gluing the next. (Alternatively, solder the scrolls on for a stronger join.) Put the plate through the spike to rest on top of the tube and glue into place. Once dry, spray the torchère with pewter enamel spray paint.
steps.visual_description: Image shows the brass tube with the head pin and prickett inserted, and scrolls being glued on. Another image shows the plate attached to the top of the tube.

tips: Cut and prepare a white cake candle (see step 2, page 37) to 1/2in long and insert on to the prickett.
projects.finished_product_description: A floor-standing torchère with a candle holder.

diagram_descriptions: Image showing the components for the torchère: two circular plates, one with a hole, and two gold-plated pins of different lengths.
Image showing the assembled torchère with a candle on top.
Image showing a close-up of the base of the torchère with decorative scrolls.
Image showing a smaller version of the torchère.

projects.name: Fighting Axe

materials.item: Thin card for black and white photocopying
Dark brown and black shoe polish
Silver and black water-based acrylic paints

steps.instruction: Photocopy the axe template on page 62 on to thin card and use small, sharp scissors to cut around the outline. Use a craft knife and a ruler to score along the line between the two 'blades'. Fold the card so the scored line is on the inside.
steps.visual_description: Two axe head shapes cut from card, one folded along a central score line.

steps.instruction: To make the shaft, take the hardwood dowel and use steel wool to apply a dark brown shoe polish, followed by black shoe polish to colour and polish the wood (see Basic Techniques page 12).
steps.visual_description: Three wooden dowels, one of which is darker and appears polished.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the end of the shaft inside the shaped card as shown. Rub tacky glue over the inside of one of the card blades and press the other into place on top. If the blades are not exactly equal, trim to match once dry.
steps.visual_description: Two card axe head shapes being glued together around the end of a wooden dowel shaft.

steps.instruction: Mix a small amount of black and silver water-based acrylic paints to make a dark silver colour. Apply a thin layer of paint to the axe head using a small paintbrush. Repeat the procedure until totally covered.
steps.visual_description: A finished axe head, painted dark silver, attached to a wooden shaft.

projects.finished_product_description: A model fighting axe made from card and a wooden dowel, painted to resemble metal.

templates.name: Axe template
templates.shape_description: Template for an axe head, consisting of two symmetrical blade shapes joined at the base, with a central score line indicated.

templates.name: Spearhead template
templates.shape_description: Template for a spearhead.

projects.name: Leather Bucket

materials.item: Black and dark brown shoe polish

steps.instruction: Photocopy and cut out the two leather bucket templates on page 61. Place the templates on the underside of the leather and cut to shape using sharp scissors. Use a darning needle to pierce through the leather where indicated on the larger template.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing two curved shapes and one circular shape, representing the templates for the bucket body and base.

steps.instruction: Take the body of the bucket and use a craft knife to remove thin slivers on the underside of the leather at one end, approximately 1/16in wide. Turn the leather over and repeat the procedure on the top side of the leather at the other end.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing a curved piece of black leather with a thin sliver being removed from the edge with a craft knife.

steps.instruction: Rub sandpaper over the leather pieces to remove the shine. Rub a small amount of black and brown shoe polish around the edges and over each side to age, but do not buff. Paint the paper-covered wire black and when dry rub over with black shoe polish.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the curved leather piece and the circular base piece, both appearing aged and slightly textured.

steps.instruction: Glue the two side edges of the bucket together, so the top of the leather overlaps the underside. Once dry, position and glue the circular base inside the bucket. Poke each end of the wire through the outside holes, forming a loop at each end.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing a finished leather bucket with a handle.

projects.finished_product_description: A small, dark-colored bucket made of leather, with a wire handle.

variation.name: Leather Mug
variation.instructions: Make a mug using the same instructions and the three mug templates on page 61. Remove thin slivers of leather on the underside of the handle at each end and then position and glue the handle on to the outside of the mug.
variation.visual_description: A small, dark-colored mug made of leather.

templates.name: Leather Bucket Templates
templates.description: Two curved shapes for the bucket body and one circular shape for the base. The larger curved shape has two small holes indicated for the handle attachment.

projects.name: Box-seat Settle

materials.purpose: front (grain to run with shortest length)

steps.instruction: Take the two pieces of wood for the arm rests and place together. Use sandpaper to shape the pieces as shown on the template on page 62. Sand and colour all of the wood components using oak-coloured shoe polish (see Basic Techniques page 12).
steps.visual_description: Four small, rectangular pieces of wood, two slightly longer than the others, with visible grain texture.

steps.instruction: Take the seat back wood piece and the two back posts and glue the posts on to each side edge of the sheet wood. The underside of the seat back and the posts should be flush with each other.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular piece of wood with two smaller rectangular pieces attached vertically to its side edges, forming a U-shape.

steps.instruction: Take a horizontal back panel and position at the top of the construction, so the panel edge is flush with the top edge of the seat back. (Note, remaining back panels are positioned once the settle has been constructed.)
steps.visual_description: A rectangular piece of wood positioned horizontally across the top of the structure created in step 2.

projects.finished_product_description: A miniature box-seat settle, a type of bench with a storage area under a sliding seat panel, resembling Tudor-era furniture.

templates.name: Arm Rests Template
templates.shape_description: Template for shaping arm rest pieces.

diagram_descriptions: A detailed, dark brown wooden miniature of a box-seat settle, showing the front with a raised seat and panelled back.
A close-up of the wooden components for the arm rests, showing four pieces of light-coloured wood with visible grain.
A close-up of a finished horizontal panel, likely for the back or front of the settle, showing a wood grain texture and a darker, aged finish.
A close-up of another finished horizontal panel, similar to the previous one, possibly for the seat or another part of the construction.

projects.name: Wooden Settle

steps.instruction: Take a side wood piece and a front post and glue the post on to one side edge of the sheet wood. The underside of the side wood piece and the post should be flush with each other.
steps.visual_description: A single piece of wood with a post glued to its side edge, flush at the bottom.

steps.instruction: Repeat the procedure described in step 4 with the remaining side wood piece and post, making this construction a mirror image of the previous one.
steps.visual_description: Two identical constructions, each consisting of a wood piece with a post glued to its side edge, flush at the bottom. They are mirror images of each other.

steps.instruction: Take the side panels and position the first panels at the top of each construction. Leave a gap of 5/8in before positioning the second horizontal panels. Position the third panels at the bottom of the constructions. Glue all the panels into place.
steps.visual_description: Two side panels, each with three horizontal wooden slats attached. The top and bottom slats are flush with the edges, and the middle slat is positioned with a 5/8 inch gap from the top slat.

steps.instruction: Turn the panelled sides over to face down, with the wider gap between the panels at the bottom of the structures. Mark 1 1/4in upwards from the bottom of each construction. Glue a seat support on the marked line on each side wood piece.
steps.visual_description: Two side panel constructions are shown face down. A horizontal line is marked 1 1/4 inches from the bottom edge of each. A seat support piece is glued onto this line.

steps.instruction: Take the front wood piece (grain to run with the shortest length) and position two horizontal front panels on top of the wood, as shown. Place the vertical front panel centrally between the horizontal panels and glue into place.
steps.visual_description: A front wood piece with two horizontal panels glued to its top surface. A vertical front panel is then glued centrally between the two horizontal panels.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the front construction between the two side constructions, with the front butting up to the end of the seat supports. Position the back construction so the inside edges of the back posts are in line with the side sheet wood pieces.
steps.visual_description: The front construction is glued between the two side constructions. The front piece butts up against the seat supports. The back construction is positioned so its inner edges align with the outer edges of the side pieces.

tips: The sliding seat of the settle would have been a useful space to store linen and other household items. See tips on page 20 for details of the contents shown here.
projects.finished_product_description: A wooden settle with a front panel, side panels, and seat supports. The image shows a finished settle with a small cloth and plate inside.

diagram_descriptions: Step 4: A single piece of wood with a post glued to its side edge, flush at the bottom.
Step 5: Two identical constructions, each consisting of a wood piece with a post glued to its side edge, flush at the bottom. They are mirror images of each other.
Step 6: Two side panels, each with three horizontal wooden slats attached. The top and bottom slats are flush with the edges, and the middle slat is positioned with a 5/8 inch gap from the top slat.
Step 7: Two side panel constructions are shown face down. A horizontal line is marked 1 1/4 inches from the bottom edge of each. A seat support piece is glued onto this line.
Step 8: A front wood piece with two horizontal panels glued to its top surface. A vertical front panel is then glued centrally between the two horizontal panels.

Step 9: The front construction is glued between the two side constructions. The front piece butts up against the seat supports. The back construction is positioned so its inner edges align with the outer edges of the side pieces.
Finished product: A wooden settle with a front panel, side panels, and seat supports. The image shows a finished settle with a small cloth and plate inside.

projects.name: Box-Seat Settle

steps.instruction: Take the base wood piece and glue it into the bottom of the box-seat settle so all outside edges are flush.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the bottom of a wooden box-seat settle with a piece of wood being glued into place.

steps.instruction: Slide the seat wood piece on to the settle. Glue a horizontal back panel on to the back immediately above the seat, allowing for the removal of the seat. Position and glue the remaining vertical back panel and horizontal back panel as shown, together with the arm rests.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the back of a wooden box-seat settle showing the seat piece and back panels being glued into place.

steps.instruction: Use a 1/16in drill bit to drill a hole centrally into the top of each back post. Glue the wooden doorknobs into place, as shown in the main photograph on page 18.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of the top of a wooden back post of a box-seat settle, showing a hole drilled centrally and a wooden doorknob being glued into place.

tips: You can create the pewter plates shown in the settle on page 19 by spraying 13/16in diameter aluminium dinner plates with pewter enamel spray paint.
Fill the settle with folded pieces of fine wool cloth and cotton to imitate bedding.
projects.finished_product_description: A rustic, painted box-seat settle with a cat lying on the seat.

diagram_descriptions: A close-up of the bottom of a wooden box-seat settle with a piece of wood being glued into place.
A close-up of the back of a wooden box-seat settle showing the seat piece and back panels being glued into place.
A close-up of two round, dark-colored plates stacked on top of each other.
A close-up of the corner of a painted wooden structure, showing distressed paint.
A close-up of the top of a wooden back post of a box-seat settle, showing a hole drilled centrally and a wooden doorknob being glued into place.
A close-up of folded pieces of textured fabric, appearing to be wool and cotton.
A finished box-seat settle, painted green, with a small, fluffy cat lying on the seat.

A room with light green walls, decorated with a classical style border at the top. A white door is on the left. A pedestal with a bust of a head stands to the right of the door. A console table with a bowl on top is in the center. A mirror with an ornate frame hangs on the wall above the console table. Two vertical wall decorations with silhouette portraits are on either side of the mirror. The text 'Classical Style' is at the bottom of the image.

projects.name: Console Table

tools.name: Sandpaper
tools.purpose: To sand edges smooth and round corners

steps.instruction: Take the wood pieces for the front and sides and glue them to the outside edges of the obecchi sheet wood piece as shown. Once dry, use fine-grade sandpaper to sand the edges smooth and to slightly round the two corners at the front of the table.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular piece of wood with two smaller pieces glued to its longer sides, forming a shallow box shape. The corners of the front piece are rounded.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the filigree decorations symmetrically to the front and sides of the table-top using tacky glue. It may be necessary to glue each side separately, allowing each to dry before continuing with the next. Cut the filigrees with small pliers to ensure a good fit.
steps.visual_description: A flat piece of wood (table-top) with decorative filigree pieces glued symmetrically to its front and side edges. There are also smaller decorative elements and beads shown.

steps.instruction: To make the legs, take a length of florist's stub wire and thread on two tube beads and two round beads, using superglue gel to fix into place. Repeat with the remaining wire and beads. Spray the table-top and legs with cream spray paint and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: A length of wire with two cylindrical beads and two round beads threaded onto it, forming a leg. Another similar leg is shown. The table-top and legs are shown painted cream.

steps.instruction: Rub over the table-top and legs with gold paste to highlight the filigrees and accentuate the fluted legs. Before gluing the marble-effect card on the top, round the corners slightly on one long side, in line with the table-top. Superglue the legs into place.
steps.visual_description: The console table with gold paste applied to highlight details. A piece of marble-effect card with rounded corners is shown, ready to be glued to the table-top. The legs are shown attached.

tips: To give a sheen to the marble-effect card, ensure that it is securely stuck to the table-top before covering it with a 3-D gloss varnish (see page 9).
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature console table with decorative filigree on the front and sides, fluted legs, and a marble-effect top.

diagram_descriptions: A drawing of a console table with two front legs and a decorative front panel.
A close-up of a rectangular piece of wood, possibly the base of the table.
A flat lay of decorative filigree pieces, beads, and wire, arranged as they would be applied to the table.
A close-up of the table-top with filigree decorations applied.
A close-up of the legs being constructed by threading beads onto wire.
A close-up of the finished console table showing the marble-effect top and gold highlighting.

projects.name: Neo-classical Mirror

steps.instruction: Take the four lengths of 3/16in x 1/16in strip wood and mitre the ends of each to an angle of 45 degrees. Position and glue the mitred wood strips together as shown. Repeat the procedure with the 1/8in x 1/16in strip wood pieces.
steps.visual_description: Two square frames made of wood strips, one slightly smaller than the other.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the 1/8in wide strip wood construction on top of the 3/16in wide strip wood construction to make a frame for the mirror and leave to dry. Use fine-grade sandpaper to sand smooth the side edges and corners of the frame.
steps.visual_description: A wooden frame with two layers of strips, showing smooth edges.

steps.instruction: Place the frame with the 3/16in wide strip wood facing upwards and position and glue the filigree decorations symmetrically around the frame, ensuring that space is left for the sconces. Cut the filigrees with small pliers if necessary to ensure a good fit.
steps.visual_description: A wooden frame decorated with gold filigree patterns, with spaces for sconces.

steps.instruction: Remove two rods on each spoke and bend into an L shape. Superglue the sconce components together and on to the frame. Spray the frame with cream spray paint. Once dry, rub over with gold paste to highlight the filigrees. Glue mirror and candles into place.
steps.visual_description: Sconce components bent into L-shapes, a fully decorated frame with mirror and candles attached.

tips: Revivals of the neo-classical style make this type of mirror suitable, more or less, up to the beginning of the 20th century.
Frames can be decorated using a variety of filigrees and jewellery findings.
Spray with old gold spray paint to achieve the effect of gilt wood.
projects.finished_product_description: A neo-classical style mirror frame decorated with gold filigree, featuring two candle sconces.

diagram_descriptions: A gilded mirror frame with two candle holders attached to the base.
Two empty square wooden frames, one slightly smaller than the other, showing the layered construction.
A single square wooden frame with intricate gold filigree decorations applied symmetrically around its edges.
A collection of small gold-colored metal components, including spoke-like pieces and circular elements, likely for attaching sconces.
A completed neo-classical mirror frame, decorated with gold filigree, with a mirror inserted and two white candles placed in the sconces.

projects.name: Pedestals

steps.instruction: Use fine-grade sandpaper to sand the edges of all of the wooden components. Position and glue two narrow sides between two wide sides, so that all outside edges are flush with each other. Repeat this procedure for the second pedestal.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a rectangular piece of wood with a layered effect, suggesting it is made of multiple pieces glued together.

steps.instruction: Take the lower top wood pieces and glue centrally to the upper top wood pieces, with the grains of each wood piece running in opposite directions to each other to prevent warping. Repeat the procedure with the lower base and upper base wood pieces.
steps.visual_description: Image shows two small square pieces of wood, with wood grain running in opposite directions on each piece.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the glued-wood sections centrally to each end of the column. Repeat for the second pedestal. Remove the peel-off stickers from the sheets and position on each side of the pedestals, ensuring the straight borders cover the joints.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a rectangular wooden piece with decorative patterns applied to its surface, resembling a section of the pedestal.

steps.instruction: Paint the pedestals with antique white acrylic paint and leave to dry. Rub a small amount of gold metallic paste lightly over each pedestal. Add character and depth by gently rubbing with wire wool to give a sheen and highlight the decorative motifs.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a rectangular wooden piece with decorative patterns, painted white and highlighted with gold metallic paste.

tips: Pedestals can be painted to represent various materials to suit home or garden from the 16th century onwards.
The pedestal sides have been reduced to 2in and filigrees used as decoration.
A plaster model was painted to match the stone-effect pedestal.
projects.finished_product_description: Decorative pedestals for display.

diagram_descriptions: Image shows two ornate, tall, rectangular pedestals, one slightly behind the other, with decorative patterns on their sides.
Image shows a close-up of a rectangular wooden piece, likely a component for the pedestal, showing its layered construction.
Image shows two small square wooden pieces, demonstrating wood grain direction.
Image shows a decorative section of a pedestal, likely with applied motifs.
Image shows a finished decorative section of a pedestal, painted and highlighted.
Image shows a finished pedestal with a small statue on top.

projects.name: Ornamental Mask

materials.item: Stone-effect paint (or grey and cream acrylic water-based paint, mixed with a little sand and tacky glue)

steps.instruction: The mould shown here is from a set of body sugar-craft moulds. Before using the mould dust it with talcum powder each time.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular mould with a face impression inside.

steps.instruction: Roll a ball of polymer clay to the required size and shape it into a teardrop as shown. Point the narrow end into the nose of the mould, pressing and smoothing the back as shown.
steps.visual_description: A teardrop-shaped piece of clay being pressed into a face mould. The back of the mould is shown smoothed.

steps.instruction: Ease the clay gently out of the mould and trim the neck. Harden the clay by baking in a domestic oven following the manufacturer's instructions. Once cool, use a 1/16in drill bit and drill a hole up through the neck.
steps.visual_description: Two clay masks with trimmed necks. A small square with an 'X' pattern is shown. A clay mask with a hole drilled through the neck is shown on a stand.

steps.instruction: Make a stand by drilling a 1/16in hole through the centre of the piece of obechi wood. Join the head and base using a short length of cocktail stick. Paint with stone-effect paint or with cream and grey acrylic paint mixed with a little sand and tacky glue.
steps.visual_description: A small square piece of wood with a hole in the center. A finished mask on a stand, painted with a stone effect.

projects.finished_product_description: A small ornamental mask made from polymer clay, designed to look like stone, mounted on a small wooden stand.

diagram_descriptions: A small bust of a classical figure, possibly a statue or a mould.
A close-up of a face mould.
A teardrop-shaped piece of polymer clay being shaped into a mask.
Two finished clay masks with trimmed necks.
A small square piece of wood with an 'X' pattern, likely a base for a stand.
A finished ornamental mask mounted on a small wooden stand.

projects.name: Neo-classical Vase

materials.item: Stone-effect paint (or grey and cream acrylic water-based paint, mixed with a little sand and tacky glue)

steps.instruction: Take a strip of quilling paper and place one end into the slot at the top of the quilling tool and begin to twist the handle. At the same time wind the paper tightly and neatly around the top of the tool until the whole strip has been coiled. Secure the ends with a dab of glue.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a quilling tool with a strip of paper being wound around it.

steps.instruction: Take another strip of quilling paper and dab glue on to one end. Place on the coil so the glued area overlaps the previous end and continue to wind around in the same way. Remove from the quilling tool and repeat the procedure, using your fingers, until the paper coil measures 3/4in diameter.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a quilling tool with a paper coil being wound around it, with the glued end overlapping the previous end. A second image shows a completed paper coil.

steps.instruction: Following the previous steps make another paper coil to measure 1 1/8in diameter. Taking one of the coils, use your fingers to gently and carefully press and ease the paper outwards to form a bowl shape. Repeat with the remaining paper coil.
steps.visual_description: Image shows two paper coils, one smaller and one larger. The larger coil is being shaped outwards with fingers to form a bowl.

steps.instruction: Paint the bowls and fill the holes inside and out with diluted tacky glue and leave to dry. Position the larger bowl on top of the upturned smaller bowl and glue into position. Paint with stone-effect paint or with a paint, sand and glue mixture.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a larger bowl placed on top of an upturned smaller bowl, forming a vase shape.

tips: It is advisable to practise making small single bowls and vases before attempting the larger vase. Follow the steps, first coiling paper to measure approximately 1/2in diameter and using the end of a pencil to press and ease it into shape. Paint your bowls and vases according to your requirements.
projects.finished_product_description: A neo-classical style vase made from coiled paper, painted to resemble stone.

diagram_descriptions: Image of a finished neo-classical vase.
Image of a quilling tool.
Image of a quilling tool with paper being wound.
Image of a completed paper coil.
Image of two paper coils, one being shaped into a bowl.
Image of a larger bowl placed on top of a smaller upturned bowl to form a vase.

projects.name: Topiary Trees

steps.instruction: Paint two cocktail sticks with brown acrylic paint to represent a tree trunk. Use the remaining cocktail sticks to temporarily hold the paper balls and paint with green acrylic paint. Once dry, cover the balls with diluted tacky glue, dip them into the scatter material and leave to dry. If the scatter coverage is insufficient repeat the procedure after the glue has totally dried.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a cocktail stick and two paper balls, one plain white and one green.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the decorative braid around the top of each plant pot. Paint with acrylic paint and once dry rub over with gold paste. Mix dry tea leaves with tacky glue and press into each pot for soil. Place a painted cocktail stick into each ball and 'plant' before the soil mixture dries.
steps.visual_description: Image shows two plant pots, one with decorative braid around the top and painted, the other with braid and painted with gold paste. The second pot also has soil mixture in it.

tips: When making topiary, unvarnished wooden beads may be used to create the rounded shapes instead of paper balls, as in the tree, far right.
projects.finished_product_description: Two small topiary trees in pots, one with a single ball top and the other with a triple ball top.

diagram_descriptions: Photo showing two finished topiary trees in pots. The tree on the left has a single ball top, and the tree on the right has a triple ball top.
Image showing a cocktail stick and two paper balls, one plain white and one green.
Image showing two plant pots, one with decorative braid around the top and painted, the other with braid and painted with gold paste. The second pot also has soil mixture in it.

projects.name: Framed Silhouettes

steps.instruction: Spray the front of the frame with black enamel spray paint. Colour photocopy the small oval-bordered silhouette templates on page 61 on to white paper.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a frame being sprayed black, and a sheet of paper with multiple small oval silhouette templates.

steps.instruction: Use small, sharp scissors to cut around the border of a silhouette. Rub a small amount of tacky glue on to the underside, then position and glue the silhouette in the centre of the black oval frame.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a silhouette being cut out with scissors, and then being glued into the center of a black oval frame.

projects.finished_product_description: A framed silhouette portrait.
tips: To antique a metal frame, spray the front with black enamel spray paint. Once dry, rub the smallest amount of gold paste over the frame to highlight any raised areas.

templates.name: Oval-bordered silhouette templates
templates.shape_description: Small oval silhouettes with borders.

templates.shape_description: Larger oval silhouettes.

A sheet of paper with six small oval silhouette templates.

A diorama scene with a country style theme. It features a light-colored wall, a wooden shelf with books and decorative plates, a small white table with a bird figurine and candles, a blue chair with books stacked on it, and a large woven basket filled with logs. A hanging basket and dried lavender are also visible. The text "Country Style" is displayed below the scene.

projects.name: Side Table

steps.instruction: Sand each of the individual wooden components. Place two legs, a short table-top support and a short leg support (positioned 1/4in from the end of each leg) in a right-angled gluing jig and glue together. Repeat the procedure with the remaining two legs and short supports.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing two legs, a short table-top support, and a short leg support assembled in a right-angled jig.

steps.instruction: Once dry, take the leg constructions and place downwards in a gluing jig. Position the long table-top supports between the leg structures and glue into place. Glue the long leg support centrally between the two short leg supports.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the two leg constructions placed downwards in a jig, with long table-top supports being positioned between them.

steps.instruction: Glue the table-top in position so that at the back the side edge is flush with the leg structure, while the remaining side edges and front overhang by 1/16in. Paint the table using water-based acrylic paints (see page 12 for distressing technique).
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the table-top being glued onto the leg structure, with an overhang at the front and sides. A close-up inset shows the finished table with a drawer and shelf.

tips: This side table was shoe polished before construction, with a false drawer and shelf added to the basic structure. Use the template on page 62 to cut out two wood pieces from 1/16in thick obechi sheet wood. Position and glue one piece under the table-top supports and the other on top of the leg supports. Glue two wooden drawer knobs to the front of the false drawer to complete the look.
projects.finished_product_description: A country-style side table, painted and distressed.

templates.name: False drawer and shelf template
templates.shape_description: Template for cutting two wood pieces for the false drawer and shelf.

diagram_descriptions: A photograph of a finished side table with a light wood finish, standing on a white background.
A diagram illustrating step 1 of the side table construction, showing the assembly of legs and supports in a jig.
A diagram illustrating step 2 of the side table construction, showing the placement of long table-top supports.
A diagram illustrating step 3 of the side table construction, showing the table-top being glued.
A close-up inset image of the finished side table, highlighting the false drawer and shelf detail.

projects.name: Side Chair

steps.instruction: Sand each of the wooden components. Position a slat and a seat support between two front legs, place into a right-angled gluing jig (see page 8) and glue into position, referring to the template on page 62.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the bottom front section of the chair being assembled in a jig. Two front legs are visible with a horizontal slat and a vertical seat support positioned between them.

steps.instruction: Position three slats and a seat support between two back legs, place into the gluing jig and glue into position, referring to the template on page 62.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the bottom back section of the chair being assembled in a jig. Two back legs are visible with three horizontal slats and a vertical seat support positioned between them.

steps.instruction: Turn the back and front constructions on their sides and place into the jig. Position and glue a slat and seat support between the leg structures and in line with the other supports. Repeat the procedure on the opposite side of the chair.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of the chair frame being assembled. The front and back leg assemblies are shown connected by slats and seat supports. The jig is visible holding the pieces in place.

steps.instruction: Take the seat piece and mark 1/8in square out of the corners on a side that has the grain running along. Remove the two sections, first cutting against the grain to avoid splitting. Glue the seat on the frame and once dry see page 12 for paint distressing.
steps.visual_description: Two square pieces of wood, likely the seat, are shown with small squares marked and cut out from their corners. The grain direction is indicated.

tips: Refer to template on page 62 for positioning.
See page 12 for paint distressing instructions.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature wooden side chair with a simple design, featuring four legs, a seat, and a back with horizontal slats.

templates.name: Side Chair Template
templates.shape_description: Used for positioning slats and seat supports during assembly. Specific details not visible in the provided image.

diagram_descriptions: A full-view image of a completed miniature wooden side chair, painted a pale green.
Diagram 1 shows the assembly of the front legs and seat support.
Diagram 2 shows the assembly of the back legs and seat support.
Diagram 3 shows the connection of the front and back leg assemblies with additional slats and supports.
Diagram 4 shows the seat piece with corner sections marked for removal.

projects.name: Wall Shelves

steps.instruction: Take a back support wood piece and mark 1/8in along from one corner of the wood. Join the mark to the corner opposite and remove the triangular section. Use fine-grade sandpaper to gently sand the wood smooth. Repeat the procedure with the other back support.
steps.visual_description: Three pieces of wood. The first piece is a rectangular strip. The second and third pieces are also rectangular strips, with a triangular section removed from one corner, creating a beveled edge.

steps.instruction: Take the side wood pieces and mark 5/16in along from one corner on each and remove the triangular sections. Wind a piece of fine-grade sandpaper around the piece of dowel, place the two side wood pieces together and sand and shape the cut sections of the wood as shown.
steps.visual_description: Three pieces of wood. The first piece is a rectangular strip. The second and third pieces are rectangular strips with a triangular section removed from one corner, creating a beveled edge. The beveled edges are shown together, suggesting they will be sanded to match.

steps.instruction: Position the side wood pieces to be a mirror image of each other. From the straight end on each, mark across at 1/8in and then 1in. Sand the remaining wooden components using fine-grade sandpaper and then stain with a light brown wood stain.
steps.visual_description: Two pieces of wood, positioned as mirror images. Each piece has two pencil marks across its width, one at 1/8in from the straight end and another at 1in from the straight end. The pieces are shown with the marked sections ready for sanding.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the back supports on top of the side wood pieces as shown, keeping all side edges flush. Take the two shelf wood pieces and position and glue the ends of each in line with the pencil marks on the shelf sides.
steps.visual_description: Two pieces of wood, representing the back supports, are shown positioned on top of the side wood pieces. The shelf wood pieces are shown positioned to be glued to the side pieces, with their ends aligned with pencil marks.

projects.finished_product_description: A two-tiered wall shelf made of wood.

diagram_descriptions: A finished two-tiered wall shelf, made of light brown wood, shown from the front.
A finished two-tiered wall shelf, made of light brown wood, shown from the front.
Three pieces of wood, two of which have a triangular section removed from one corner, creating a beveled edge.
Three pieces of wood, two of which have a triangular section removed from one corner, creating a beveled edge.
Two pieces of wood, positioned as mirror images, with pencil marks indicating where to sand.
Two pieces of wood, representing back supports, positioned on top of side pieces, and two shelf pieces positioned to be glued.

projects.name: Books

steps.instruction: Take the 1/2in x 3/32in strip of wood and use fine-grade sandpaper to gently round one long side edge, to create the effect of the book spine. Cut the strip into 5/8in lengths using either a mitre block and saw or mitre cutters. Sand any rough edges.
steps.visual_description: A strip of wood being rounded on one edge, and then cut into smaller pieces.

steps.instruction: Cut out a book cover from the pastel paper and rub the outside of the paper with a small amount of shoe polish or gold metallic paste to age it. Rub paste or shoe polish along the straight outside edges of a wooden block to create the effect of the pages.
steps.visual_description: A piece of pastel paper being aged with shoe polish or gold paste, and a wooden block with its edges treated to look like pages.

steps.instruction: Rub a thin, even layer of tacky glue on the inside of the book cover and glue on to the block of wood. Use the blunt edge of a knife to make horizontal indentations on the spine of the book. Make more books using the remaining strip wood - see guide, left.
steps.visual_description: A book cover being glued to a wooden block, and indentations being made on the spine.

steps.instruction: As an alternative to making paper book covers, paint some wooden blocks using water-based acrylic paints. Age the painted cover by lightly rubbing over shoe polish or gold paste. Position the painted books between paper-covered books for best results.
steps.visual_description: Painted wooden blocks that have been aged, and a stack of paper-covered books.

tips: Follow the guide below to make different sized books
projects.finished_product_description: Miniature books made from wood strips and paper, designed to look like a pile or row of books on a shelf.

diagram_descriptions: A row of miniature books with purple covers, standing upright.
Two strips of light purple wood, one longer than the other, with two smaller pieces below.
A light purple wooden block with a strip of wood on top, and a separate thin strip of wood standing upright.
Two small purple squares, one slightly lighter than the other.
A stack of miniature purple books, lying flat.
A thin strip of purple wood standing upright.
Two small purple squares, one slightly lighter than the other.

projects.name: Log Basket

tools.name: mitre cutters or a saw and mitre block
tools.purpose: to cut dried twigs to fill your basket with miniature logs

steps.instruction: Stain all of the paper-covered wire with medium oak wood stain and leave to dry. Lay four stakes centrally on top of the remaining five stakes as shown above.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows four stakes laid horizontally, crossed by five vertical stakes in the center, forming a cross shape.

steps.instruction: Take the waxed thread and fold over a 5in length to form a loop. Begin to secure the stakes together by placing the loop around one group of stakes as shown above.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows the cross shape of stakes from step 1. A loop of waxed thread is placed around the central intersection of the stakes.

steps.instruction: Take the thread that is under the first group of stakes, over the top of the second group of stakes. The thread that is over the first group should be brought under the second group of stakes.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows the stakes and thread from step 2. The thread is being woven around the stakes in an under-and-over pattern.

steps.instruction: Continue this under-and-over pattern neatly and evenly around the groups of stakes in three full circles. Trim the short excess length of weaving thread, dabbing on a tiny amount of tacky glue to hold it in place.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows the stakes with the thread woven around them in a circular pattern, forming a square base. The thread has been woven around three times.

tips: Use mitre cutters or a saw and mitre block (shown on page 12) to cut dried twigs to fill your basket with miniature logs.
projects.finished_product_description: A woven basket filled with miniature logs.

diagram_descriptions: A woven basket filled with cut logs.
Diagram showing four stakes laid horizontally, crossed by five vertical stakes in the center, forming a cross shape.
Diagram showing the cross shape of stakes from step 1. A loop of waxed thread is placed around the central intersection of the stakes.
Diagram showing the stakes and thread from step 2. The thread is being woven around the stakes in an under-and-over pattern.
Diagram showing the stakes with the thread woven around them in a circular pattern, forming a square base. The thread has been woven around three times.

projects.name: Log Basket

steps.instruction: Cut off one stake with wire cutters to leave seventeen - an uneven number is needed to weave alternately in and out of each stake. Begin to weave between the stakes, opening them out as you do so.
steps.visual_description: Top-down view of stakes arranged in a cross shape with weaving starting in the center.

steps.instruction: Ensure the stakes remain evenly spaced during weaving and the weaving thread kept tight and even. Continue weaving until the base measures 1 1/8in diameter, then begin to bend the stakes upwards and outwards slightly.
steps.visual_description: A small, partially woven basket with stakes starting to bend upwards.

steps.instruction: Continue weaving until the basket is 1 1/8in high, ensuring the stakes remain slightly angled outwards. When the weaving is finished, use the end of cocktail stick to dab a tiny amount of tacky glue around the top of the basket next to the stakes.
steps.visual_description: A woven basket with stakes angled outwards, showing the top edge.

steps.instruction: Once the glue has dried, trim the stakes to the height of the woven thread using wire cutters. Trim the excess weaving thread and dab a tiny amount of tacky glue on the end to hold it in place inside the basket.
steps.visual_description: A woven basket with trimmed stakes and a close-up of the top edge showing glue application.

steps.instruction: To make the border for the top of the basket, take six 12in lengths of waxed thread and using two together, plait into a length. Trim each end and glue on to the top of the basket to hide the ends of the wire stakes.
steps.visual_description: A braided length of waxed thread and a close-up of the basket top with the braided border glued on.

steps.instruction: To make a handle, take a 1 1/2in and 1in length of wire. Place together and neatly wind around the waxed thread, leaving a 1/4in gap at each end of the wire. Use tacky glue to secure the thread at each end. Repeat with the remaining handle wires.
steps.visual_description: Two pieces of wire placed together, being wrapped with waxed thread, showing gaps at the ends.

steps.instruction: Bend the handles into shape, then take a handle and glue each wire end in through the border and between the weaving. Repeat with the remaining handle on the opposite side. Chop twigs into small lengths and use to fill up the log basket.
steps.visual_description: A handle being attached to the basket and a finished basket with a handle.

tips: If you come to the end of the thread whilst weaving, join a new length behind a stake on the inside of the basket, as above.
projects.finished_product_description: A small, rustic log basket with a handle.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing how to join a new thread during weaving.
Illustration of stakes being woven and bent outwards.
Illustration of a partially woven basket with stakes bending upwards.
Illustration of a woven basket with stakes angled outwards.
Illustration of trimmed stakes and glue application on the basket rim.
Illustration of a braided thread for the basket border.
Illustration of wire being wrapped with thread for the handle.
Illustration of a handle being attached to the basket.

projects.name: Plates

materials.item: White or cream enamel spray paints

steps.instruction: Spray an aluminium plate front and back with enamel spray paint. Trim excess paper from around the transfer and then soak in a dish of water for several minutes until the transfer separates from the paper backing.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a plate being sprayed, a transfer being trimmed, and a transfer soaking in water.

steps.instruction: Rub a small amount of tacky glue over the middle of the plate and place the transfer centrally on the plate, smoothing out any air bubbles. Once dry, cover the plate with diluted tacky glue to cover and conceal the edge of the transfer.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a transfer being applied to a plate with glue, and then a plate covered with glue.

projects.finished_product_description: Decorated plates with water-slide transfers.

projects.name: Ribbon Plates

materials.item: White or cream enamel spray paints

steps.instruction: Take a paper plate and use a 1/16in paper punch to pierce an even number of holes around the border. The plate shown here has twenty holes, with a gap of approximately 1/16in between each. Paint the front and back of the plate with enamel spray paint.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a paper plate with holes punched around the border, and a plate being painted.

steps.instruction: Follow the instructions in steps 1 and 2 from the basic plate above to apply and cover the transfer. Thread the ribbon in and out of the holes on the plate using a needle. Trim each end of the ribbon and glue to the back of the plate.
steps.visual_description: Image shows ribbon being threaded through holes on a plate, and the ends of the ribbon being glued to the back.

projects.finished_product_description: Paper plates decorated with transfers and ribbon threaded through punched holes.

diagram_descriptions: Image showing two small decorative plates with floral transfers.
Image showing a plain aluminium plate and a plate with a floral transfer applied.
Image showing a plain aluminium plate and a plate with a floral transfer applied.
Image showing three paper plates with punched holes around the edges, in various stages of completion.
Image showing a needle threading ribbon through the holes of a decorated paper plate.

projects.name: Candlesticks and Snuffer

steps.instruction: Take a brass eyelet and place it wide side down. Insert a gold-plated spacer bead into the upturned opening of the eyelet using superglue gel to secure it. Repeat the procedure for the second candlestick.
steps.visual_description: Three brass eyelets and one gold-plated spacer bead are shown. One eyelet has a spacer bead inserted into its opening.

steps.instruction: Take the candle and cut two 3/4in lengths. To avoid the wax fracturing, roll the candle backwards and forwards whilst using a craft knife to slice through the wax and cut the wick. Remove 1/8in of wax on each candle to reveal the wick and then insert into the holders.
steps.visual_description: A candle is shown with dashed lines indicating where to cut. Another image shows a candle wick exposed.

steps.instruction: To achieve the effect of burnt candles, light the candles and let them burn part of the way down. Cut the wick down to size, as it will not have burnt as quickly as the wax, then colour the wick with black water-based acrylic paint.
steps.visual_description: Four brass eyelets with candle wicks inserted are shown. Some wicks are longer than others.

steps.instruction: To make the snuffer, take the gold-plated bell cap and head pin. Cut the head pin to measure 3/4in long and slide the eye of the bell cap along to the end of the head pin, gluing into place with superglue gel.
steps.visual_description: A gold-plated head pin and a gold-plated bell cap are shown. Another image shows the bell cap slid onto the head pin.

projects.finished_product_description: Candlesticks and a snuffer made from brass eyelets, beads, and candles.

diagram_descriptions: Two small, finished candlesticks decorated with silver tinsel.
A close-up of the materials needed: two brass eyelets, one gold-plated spacer bead, and a gold-plated snuffer component.
A diagram showing the assembly of the candlestick base with a brass eyelet and spacer bead.
A diagram showing the preparation of the candle wick.
A diagram showing the assembly of the snuffer with a bell cap and head pin.

projects.name: Decoy Duck

materials.item: Black and cream water-based acrylic paints

steps.instruction: Take the cold porcelain modelling paste and roll out a 3/8in diameter ball. Simply shape the ball into the body of a duck. Roll out a 1/4in diameter ball for the head and a 1/16in ball and shape into a beak.
steps.visual_description: Three small balls of modelling paste, one larger than the others, and a very small one shaped into a beak.

steps.instruction: Attach the head and beak to the duck's body using a dab of tacky glue. Cut the stub wire to measure 1in long and insert into the base of the duck. Place the opposite end of the wire into a temporary holder, such as florist's foam, until the duck is dry and firm.
steps.visual_description: A duck body with a head and beak attached, with a piece of wire inserted into the base and the other end stuck into a block of foam.

steps.instruction: Cover the duck with a light coat of medium oak wood stain. Once dry, lightly cover the top of the head, body and beak with black acrylic paint. Use a fine paintbrush to stroke cream paint over side of the face and breast. Use black enamel for the eyes.
steps.visual_description: A finished decoy duck with a brown body, black accents on the head and back, and cream paint on the face and breast. The eyes are black dots.

steps.instruction: To make the stand, drill a 3/64in hole in the centre of the wooden block. Sand the block and then paint with black acrylic paint. Follow the paint distressing instructions on page 12 to age and add character to the stand. To finish, glue the wire into the wooden block.
steps.visual_description: Four small wooden blocks, one with a hole drilled in the center, and a finished decoy duck standing on a block.

projects.finished_product_description: A carved wooden decoy duck mounted on a small wooden block.

diagram_descriptions: A small, finished decoy duck on a stand.
Three small, unpainted duck bodies and a beak.
A block of foam with a wire inserted into it, with a decoy duck attached to the wire.
A finished decoy duck with a brown body, black accents, and cream highlights.
Four small wooden blocks, one with a hole drilled in the center, and a finished decoy duck standing on a block.
A silhouette of a duck on a stake.
Three small decoy ducks standing on a block of foam.

A miniature scene depicting a Victorian entryway with red textured wallpaper, a dark wooden door with a stained-glass panel featuring a Celtic knot design in yellow, red, and green. To the left, a wall sconce with a frosted glass shade and brass base, and a framed picture above a small wooden stand holding a potted plant in a purple pot. To the right, a coat rack with a hat and a dark coat hanging, a wall sconce, and several framed pictures. In the foreground, a wooden stand holding various canes and umbrellas, with a black handbag on the floor. The floor is tiled with a geometric pattern. The title 'Victorian Values' is printed below the scene.

projects.name: Hat and Coat Rack

materials.item: Dark wood stain or shoe polish

steps.instruction: Transfer the coat and hat rack side template on page 62 on to the two pieces of sheet wood and use mitre cutters or a craft knife to remove excess wood. Sand the edges smooth using fine-grade sandpaper. Sand the strip wood pieces too.
steps.visual_description: Two triangular pieces of wood, representing the sides of the rack.

steps.instruction: Take the hook support and transfer the drill hole positions from the template on page 62 on to the wood piece. Use a 1/16in drill bit to drill the holes part-way through the wood. Use a dark-coloured wood stain or shoe polish on all of the wooden components.
steps.visual_description: Two pieces of wood strip with pre-drilled holes, showing the positions for the hooks.

steps.instruction: Remove part of the straight section of wood from the belaying pins using mitre cutters, leaving 1/16in attached to the turned head. Glue the straight ends of the belaying pins into the holes on the hook support.
steps.visual_description: Four wooden belaying pins, with a portion of the straight section removed, ready to be inserted into a wooden strip.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the hook support and back support between the two sides and leave to dry. Referring to the main photograph at the top of the page, glue two slats on top of the rack, in line with the back and front, and the other three slats in between.
steps.visual_description: A partially assembled hat and coat rack, showing the sides, hook support, and back support glued together. The slats are yet to be attached.

projects.finished_product_description: A wooden hat and coat rack with three hooks.

templates.name: coat and hat rack side template
templates.shape_description: Template for the side pieces of the hat and coat rack.

templates.name: hook support template
templates.shape_description: Template showing drill hole positions for the hook support.

diagram_descriptions: A finished wooden hat and coat rack with a top shelf and three hooks.
Two triangular pieces of wood, representing the sides of the rack.
Two pieces of wood strip with pre-drilled holes, showing the positions for the hooks.
Four wooden belaying pins, with a portion of the straight section removed, ready to be inserted into a wooden strip.
A partially assembled hat and coat rack, showing the sides, hook support, and back support glued together. The slats are yet to be attached.

projects.name: Boater

steps.instruction: The crown of the boater is made by moulding the canvas over a hat block, such as a bottle top or wooden dowel measuring approximately 3/4in diameter. Cut a piece of canvas 2 1/2in x 2 1/2in and soak in warm water for a minute.
steps.visual_description: A clear cylindrical object, possibly a bottle top or dowel, with a circular opening at the top.

steps.instruction: Place the soaked canvas around the top of the mould and hold in place with a small elastic band. Manipulate the material until the canvas on top of the mould is flat and the outside, above the elastic band, is smooth. Once totally dry, remove and trim to measure 1/4in high.
steps.visual_description: A piece of fabric, held in place by a red elastic band, is moulded around a cylindrical object. A separate circular piece of fabric is shown next to it.

steps.instruction: Cover a 1 1/2in x 1 1/2in piece of canvas on one side with diluted tacky glue and leave to dry. Draw a 1 3/8in diameter circle on the glued side (underside) of the canvas, followed by a circle in the centre slightly smaller than the size of the crown and cut out.
steps.visual_description: Two circular pieces of fabric. One is a solid circle, and the other is a ring shape.

steps.instruction: Glue the crown on to the brim, with the glued side downwards. Trim the boater with a length of 3mm black silk ribbon. Make a bow as described on page 54, remove the ends and then flatten and glue it on, to cover the join in the ribbon band.
steps.visual_description: A finished boater hat with a dark ribbon band and a small bow. A separate small black bow is shown next to the hat.

tips: Felt or leather may be used as alternative materials.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature boater hat made from canvas, with a ribbon band and bow.

diagram_descriptions: A small, finished boater hat with a dark ribbon band and bow.
A clear cylindrical object, possibly a bottle top or dowel, used as a mould.
A piece of fabric, held in place by a red elastic band, being moulded around a cylindrical object. A separate circular piece of fabric is shown next to it.
Two circular pieces of fabric. One is a solid circle, and the other is a ring shape.
A finished boater hat with a dark ribbon band and a small bow. A separate small black bow is shown next to the hat.

projects.name: Stick Stand

materials.item: Dark wood stain or shoe polish
Black and silver water-based acrylic paints

steps.instruction: Transfer the tray measurements from the template on page 62 on to the thick card and cut out. Paint the card with a mixture of black and silver acrylic paint to give the effect of a metallic tray base. Once dry, repeat the procedure on the other side of the card.
steps.visual_description: A dark rectangular shape with a stepped edge, representing the tray base.

steps.instruction: Sand and stain or shoe polish the wooden components. Take two legs and on each mark 1/8in along from each end. Place into a right-angled gluing jig (see page 8) and position and glue two front supports between the legs, as shown. Repeat with the remaining legs and back supports.
steps.visual_description: Two wooden legs are shown with two horizontal supports glued between them, forming a rectangular frame. A second image shows a similar frame, but with two additional supports creating a divided tray base.

steps.instruction: Place the front and back sections into the gluing jig and glue the two side supports between, as shown. Once dry, position and glue two supports centrally into the stand and the remaining ones on to the opposite side.
steps.visual_description: A partially assembled stick stand frame is shown, with side supports being glued between the front and back sections. A second image shows the frame with additional central supports being added.

steps.instruction: Position and glue the tray underneath the stand. To complete, glue the squares of sheet wood on top of the legs.
steps.visual_description: A completed stick stand is shown from a top-down perspective, with the tray base glued in place and small squares of wood glued to the top of the legs.

projects.finished_product_description: A miniature wooden stick stand with a divided tray base.

tools_reference.name: gluing jig
tools_reference.use: To hold components at right angles for gluing

templates.name: Tray Template
templates.shape_description: A rectangular shape with stepped edges, used for the tray base.

diagram_descriptions: A large, dark wooden stick stand with four legs and a divided tray base.
A close-up of the tray base, showing its stepped rectangular shape.
A close-up of the wooden components of the stick stand, showing the legs and supports.

A partially assembled stick stand frame, showing the attachment of central supports.
