projects.name: Silver-topped Stick

steps.instruction: Stain or shoe polish a length of dowel. Shave one end and glue on a silver bead. Wind a length of aluminium foil around the shaft below the bead and glue in place for a collar. Repeat with another piece of foil to make a ferrule (tip) and glue into place. Touch up each end of the stick with silver acrylic paint.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two dowel pieces, one with a bead and foil collar, the other with a bead and foil ferrule.

projects.finished_product_description: A walking stick with a silver bead and foil decoration at the top and a ferrule at the bottom.

projects.name: Ebony Stick

steps.instruction: Take a length of dowel and paint with black enamel paint. Once dry, make a knob (using a black bead), collar and ferrule for the stick, as described left.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a black dowel with a bead at one end and a ferrule at the other.

projects.finished_product_description: A walking stick painted black with a bead knob and ferrule.

projects.name: Curved-handled Stick

steps.instruction: Soak a 5in length of size 3 centre cane in warm water for 20 minutes and then bend one end over a pencil. Hold in place with a clothes peg and straighten the opposite end. Once dry, trim the handle and stick to 3 1/8in. Make a ferrule, as described above.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a cane bent over a pencil with a clothes peg holding it in place.

projects.finished_product_description: A walking stick with a curved handle and a ferrule.

projects.name: Variation: Porcelain Knobs

steps.instruction: Follow the instructions for the silver-topped stick but replace the silver bead with a porcelain or opaque glass bead. Wind 28-gauge wire immediately below the bead as an alternative collar. Gold foil is available from craft shops and can be used as an alternative to aluminium foil.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing several walking sticks with different colored bead tops and wire collars.

projects.finished_product_description: Walking sticks decorated with porcelain or glass beads and wire collars.

diagram_descriptions: Image of three walking sticks: one with a silver top, one black, and one with a curved handle.
Diagram showing the components for a silver-topped stick: dowel, bead, foil collar, and ferrule.
Diagram showing the components for an ebony stick: dowel, bead, and ferrule.
Diagram showing a cane being bent over a pencil with a clothes peg.
Image of a wooden stand holding several walking sticks with various decorative tops.
Image of several walking sticks with different colored bead tops and wire collars.

projects.name: Plant Stand

materials.item: Dark wood stain or shoe polish

tools.name: mitre cutters or a craft knife

steps.instruction: Take a wood piece and use a pencil and ruler to draw a line from corner to corner to find the centre. Measure and mark 3/16in along from each corner then join the marks using a pencil and ruler.
steps.visual_description: Two square wood pieces with diagonal lines drawn from corner to corner, and marks along the edges.

steps.instruction: Remove the corner sections using either mitre cutters or a craft knife. Chamfer the edges of the wood piece, on the side without the pencil marks, to an angle of 45 degrees using fine-grade sandpaper (see Basic Techniques page 12). Repeat steps 1 and 2 with the second piece of wood.
steps.visual_description: Two octagonal wood pieces, one with a central hole, the other with a partial hole.

steps.instruction: Measure the diameter of the wide end of your spindle and using the same sized drill bit, drill a hole centrally straight through a wood piece for the base. On the second piece, drill a hole the same size but only half way through for the top.
steps.visual_description: Two octagonal wood pieces, one with a central hole, the other with a partial hole.

steps.instruction: Cut the narrow end off the spindle and sand smooth. Stain or shoe polish all the wooden components. Glue the straight end of the spindle into the base, chamfered side up. Glue the top into position, with the wood grain of both pieces in line with the base.
steps.visual_description: Two turned wooden spindles, one with a wider end and a narrower end, the other with both ends turned.

tips: For a more contemporary look make a plant stand as described above but decorate it with a distressed paint finish in cream or a colour to complement your dolls' house décor (see page 12 for distressing technique instructions).
projects.finished_product_description: A small, turned wooden plant stand with a hexagonal base and top, and a turned central column with decorative rings.

diagram_descriptions: A finished wooden plant stand with a hexagonal base and top, and a turned central column with decorative rings.
Four diagrams illustrating steps 1 and 2: a square piece of wood with diagonal lines and marks, two octagonal pieces of wood with central markings, and two turned wooden spindles.
A photograph of a plant stand with a plant on top, showing a variation with a distressed paint finish.

projects.name: Aspidistra

steps.instruction: Cut twelve strips of floral tape into varying lengths ranging from 2 1/2in to 1 1/2in. Take a piece of floral tape and cover one half of the tape on one side with a thin layer of tacky glue. Place the wire centrally on the glued section of the tape, as shown.
steps.visual_description: Two rectangular strips of floral tape with a thin wire placed centrally on one half of each strip.

steps.instruction: Fold the tape over, so the wire is sandwiched between the tape. Press firmly, then slightly pull the end of the wire so the wire isn't right at the end of the fold. Repeat the procedure with the remaining materials and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: A folded piece of floral tape with a wire inside, showing the wire slightly pulled from the end. A small pot filled with many green stems is shown to the right.

steps.instruction: Transfer the leaf template from page 61 on to the longest floral tape pieces. Alter the length and width of the leaf accordingly and cut out the shapes. Trim the wire ends to 1in. Make soil by mixing dry tea leaves with tacky glue and press into your plant pot.
steps.visual_description: Two leaf shapes cut from floral tape, one longer than the other, each with a wire extending from the base. A small pot filled with soil made from tea leaves is shown below.

steps.instruction: Immediately position the leaves into the pot starting with the smallest in the centre and working outwards and leaving the stems visible. Once the soil has dried out, refer to the main photograph and bend the leaves into position.
steps.visual_description: A small pot with several green leaves positioned in the soil, with stems visible. The finished Aspidistra plant is shown to the right.

tips: Paint a fine line of antique white acrylic paint centrally along each side of the tape before it dries to give a variegated effect to the leaf.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature Aspidistra houseplant made from floral tape and wire, planted in a small pot with a soil made from tea leaves.

templates.name: Leaf template
templates.shape_description: A template for cutting leaf shapes from floral tape, with varying lengths and widths.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing two pieces of floral tape with wires attached, illustrating step 1.
Diagram showing a folded piece of floral tape with a wire, illustrating step 2.
Diagram showing two cut leaf shapes from floral tape with wires, illustrating step 3.
Photograph of a finished miniature Aspidistra plant in a pot.
Photograph of a potted Aspidistra plant with many leaves.

projects.name: Framed Photographs

steps.instruction: Colour photocopy the sepia prints on page 61 onto white card. Use paper punches to punch holes out of the coloured paper to make a mount for each of the photographs, ensuring that the aperture is no larger than the photograph.
steps.visual_description: A piece of light green card with various shapes punched out (circles, square, rectangle) and several small sepia photographs placed on top.

steps.instruction: Cut out the photographs, leaving a small border around the outside. Cut the mounts to size, leaving no more than 1/4in border around the aperture. Position and glue the photograph to the back of the mount.
steps.visual_description: A small framed photograph with a sepia image of a man and woman inside a mount with a circular aperture.

steps.instruction: Stain the lengths of strip wood and then make a frame for each photograph (see page 12). The frame should measure slightly larger than the outside edges of the mount. Alternatively, use moulded picture framing wood to frame the photographs.
steps.visual_description: A small square frame with a square mount inside, showing a sepia photograph of a group of people.

tips: Make small photograph frames out of metal frames used for egg decorating. They can be sprayed and antiqued (see tip on page 28), tarnished using wood stain or left in their natural state. Cut a photograph to fit and glue into position. Make a stand for the frame by folding a small strip of card into a V shape and gluing it to the back of the frame.
projects.finished_product_description: Miniature framed photographs in various styles and sizes, some with ornate frames.

diagram_descriptions: A collection of small, ornate, gold-colored frames, some containing sepia photographs.
A miniature wooden table with several small framed photographs and decorative items on top.
A light green card with various shapes punched out (circles, square, rectangle) and several small sepia photographs placed on top.

A small square frame with a square mount inside, showing a sepia photograph of a group of people.

projects.name: Decorative Bottles and Jars

steps.instruction: Make decorative bottles and jars with glass and ceramic beads which have brass knobs or 2mm diameter up-eyes inserted.
steps.visual_description: Several glass and ceramic beads, some with brass knobs and some with up-eyes inserted, are shown. One bead is amber colored and appears to be a bottle shape. Another is black and appears to be a jar shape. There are also small brass knob and up-eye findings.

steps.instruction: An interesting display of bottles can be made using a variety of different sized and shaped beads and up-eyes.
steps.visual_description: The image shows a variety of beads and findings that can be used to create decorative bottles and jars.

steps.instruction: Gold plated up-eyes are also available.
steps.visual_description: The image shows various beads and findings, including gold-plated up-eyes.

projects.finished_product_description: Decorative bottles and jars made from beads and findings.

projects.name: Lidded Pots

steps.instruction: Make lidded pots from glass and ceramic beads topped with 6mm gold-plated decorative caps.
steps.visual_description: Several glass and ceramic beads are shown, some topped with gold-plated decorative caps. One bead is purple with a floral design, another is green. The caps have raised patterns.

steps.instruction: The relief pattern on some caps enables them to be enamelled.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of a gold-plated cap showing a relief pattern that can be filled with enamel.

steps.instruction: Dip a cocktail stick into enamel paint and allow a small droplet to fall into the area to be decorated.
steps.visual_description: A cocktail stick is shown being dipped into a small pot of paint.

projects.finished_product_description: Small lidded pots made from beads and decorative caps.

projects.name: Trinket Dishes

steps.instruction: Make dishes from nickel eyelets with 10mm up-eyes inserted into the narrow end.
steps.visual_description: Several nickel eyelets are shown, some with 10mm up-eyes inserted into their narrow ends. These are arranged to resemble small dishes.

steps.instruction: Make a decorative pot using an 8mm diameter bead cap, topped with a 6mm up-eye.
steps.visual_description: An 8mm diameter bead cap is shown, with a 6mm up-eye attached to its top, forming a small decorative pot.

steps.instruction: Make a trinket pot from an eyelet, capped with a 6mm up-eye.
steps.visual_description: A nickel eyelet is shown, capped with a 6mm up-eye, forming a trinket pot.

projects.finished_product_description: Small trinket dishes and decorative pots made from eyelets and beads.

projects.name: Bells

tools.name: pliers
tools.purpose: to remove clapper and trim wood

steps.instruction: Take the bell and remove the clapper using a small pair of pliers.
steps.visual_description: A small bell is shown. A pair of pliers is indicated as the tool to remove the clapper.

steps.instruction: Remove part of the straight section of the wood from a 14mm belaying pin, leaving 1/8in attached to the turned head.
steps.visual_description: A 14mm wooden belaying pin is shown. A section of the straight part is indicated to be removed, leaving a small portion attached to the head.

steps.instruction: Stain and then glue this into the top of the bell.
steps.visual_description: The prepared wooden piece is shown being glued into the top opening of the bell.

projects.finished_product_description: Decorative bells made from existing bells and wooden pins.

projects.name: Variation: Pot-pourri Dishes

steps.instruction: Dishes can be filled with 1mm diameter no-hole beads to represent bon-bons or with fragments of dried flowers to represent pot-pourri.
steps.visual_description: Two finished decorative dishes are shown. One is filled with small, round, brown beads resembling bon-bons. The other is filled with small, colorful fragments resembling dried flowers for pot-pourri.

projects.finished_product_description: Decorative dishes filled with beads or dried flowers.

tools_reference.use: To remove clappers from bells and trim small parts.

projects.name: Bracket Lamps

steps.instruction: Transfer the bracket lamp template on page 62 on to paper or card. Take a length of brass tube and with two pairs of small pliers, bend into the shape shown on the drawing. Repeat the procedure with the remaining piece of brass tube.
steps.visual_description: A straight brass tube, a bent brass tube in a zig-zag shape, and two small gold-plated bells with a bead and a decorative disc.

steps.instruction: Use a small pair of pliers to remove the clappers from the bells. Check that the brass tube threads through the holes in the bells, the shades and the loop on each of the up-eyes. If you have difficulty, widen the holes carefully using a pin file.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of a gold-plated bell with its clapper removed, a gold-plated bead, and a decorative gold-plated disc.

steps.instruction: Thread the bell on to the brass tube, then position the shade on top of the upturned bell, so the end of the brass tube is just visible in the shade. Superglue into place, then repeat with the other lamp.
steps.visual_description: A brass tube with a bell threaded onto it, and a frosted shade placed on top of the bell. Another brass tube is shown separately.

steps.instruction: Use tacky glue to fix the clear plastic tube inside the base of the shade. Slide the brass tube on to the cap - do not glue, to enable the lamp to swing. Cut a head pin to 1/4in and glue into the protruding end of the brass tube. Repeat for the second lamp.
steps.visual_description: A partially assembled lamp showing a clear plastic tube inside a shade, a brass tube attached to a cap, and a head pin glued to the end of the brass tube.

projects.finished_product_description: A decorative bracket lamp made from brass tubing, bells, and frosted shades.

templates.shape_description: A template for bending brass tube into a zig-zag shape.

projects.name: Oil Lamp

steps.instruction: Use a 1/32in drill bit to drill a hole part of the way through the side of the corrugated ring bead. Cut the head pin to measure 3/16in and superglue the straight end into the drilled hole. Use a 1/16in drill bit to drill a hole through the side of the bead cap, for electrification.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a head pin being inserted into a drilled bead, and a bead cap with a drilled hole.

steps.instruction: Glue the cap, tube and cushion beads together as shown, followed by the corrugated ring and shade. Thread the wires from the bulb down through the shade and out of the hole in the base. Rest the plastic tube in the shade, without gluing to allow replacement of the bulb.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing the assembled oil lamp base with a bulb and wires threaded through.

projects.finished_product_description: A decorative oil lamp made from beads and a frosted flower shade.

projects.name: Tiffany Lamp

steps.instruction: Take the filigree shade and lightly spray inside and out with black spray paint. Take a cocktail stick, dip it into the glass paint and begin to fill the gaps in the shade symmetrically, allowing each colour to dry before continuing with the next.
steps.visual_description: Image showing three filigree shades, one gold, two dark. The dark ones appear to have colored glass filling the gaps.

steps.instruction: Take the spoke and use pliers to slightly lift the loops at each end. Superglue the lamp stand together, following the oil lamp instructions for electrification details. Rest the shade on top of the upturned spokes – do not glue, to allow easy replacement of the bulb.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a gold-plated spoke with loops, and an assembled lamp stand with a bead base and the filigree shade resting on top.

projects.finished_product_description: A Tiffany-style table lamp with a decorative filigree shade.

diagram_descriptions: Two finished table lamps, one with a frosted flower shade and the other a Tiffany-style lamp with a filigree shade.
Close-up of components for the oil lamp: a head pin, two small beads, and a larger decorative bead.
Close-up of components for the Tiffany lamp: three filigree shades of different finishes.

projects.name: Papier Mâché Letter Rack

materials.item: water-slide transfers (decals) or acrylic water-based paints

steps.instruction: Transfer the letter rack templates on page 62 on to a piece of 1/32in thickness card. Use a sharp craft knife to score the card where indicated. Make a hole at the top of the rack using a 1/16in diameter paper punch.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a piece of card with score lines and a hole at the top, and three smaller rectangular pieces.

steps.instruction: Take the back piece of card and from the base, measure and mark with a pencil the following positions - 1/8in, 9/16in and 1in.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a rectangular piece of card with three horizontal score lines marked from the bottom edge.

steps.instruction: Take a letter holder and fold the sides down so the scored lines face outwards. Position and glue on to the back piece, so the base of the letter holder rests centrally on a marked line. Repeat the procedure with the remaining card pieces and leave to dry.
steps.visual_description: Image shows three folded card pieces, resembling small boxes, and a larger card piece with score lines. The folded pieces are being glued onto the larger piece.

steps.instruction: Paint the letter rack with black water-based enamel paint. Decorate the letter holders either by painting or using water-slide transfers soaked off and smoothed on to the front of each one. Highlight the outside edges of the back and holders with gold paste.
steps.visual_description: Image shows a finished black letter rack with three compartments, decorated with floral transfers. There are also separate floral transfers shown.

tips: Moulded papier mâché trays were a practical but decorative household item, popular in many Victorian homes. Trays can either be purchased and painted or sprayed with black enamel paint, or made out of card and decorated as described in step 4.
projects.finished_product_description: A letter rack made from card, painted black and decorated with floral transfers and gold paste highlights.

A garland of greenery with pinecones and bows hangs above the fireplace. A paper chain garland is strung across the top of the room. projects.name: Coal Box

materials.item: Wooden double column or small wooden drawer knob

steps.instruction: Transfer the coal box side template (page 62) on to the two side pieces of obecchi sheet wood. Use a craft knife and ruler to cut out the shape, then sand any rough edges using fine-grade sandpaper.
steps.visual_description: Two trapezoidal pieces of light-colored wood, one with a slightly curved top edge.

steps.instruction: Take the front wood piece and chamfer the edge of one long side to an angle of 60 degrees using fine-grade sandpaper (see Basic Techniques page 12).
steps.visual_description: A rectangular piece of light-colored wood with one long edge beveled at an angle.

steps.instruction: Take the double column and cut where shown to make a drawer knob. Sand the knob and the remaining wood pieces smooth using fine-grade sandpaper. Use a dark brown shoe polish to colour all of the wooden components (see page 12).
steps.visual_description: Several small pieces of light-colored wood. One piece is cylindrical and appears to be a knob. Other pieces are small blocks and a thin strip.

steps.instruction: Take the side wood pieces and position so they are a mirror image of each other. Transfer the ledge measurements from page 62 on to each piece, then position and glue the two top supports into place.
steps.visual_description: Two trapezoidal pieces of wood with a wood grain pattern, positioned as mirror images. The top edges are angled.

tips: Due to improvements in transport during the mid 19th century, coal became a cheap and reliable source of domestic fuel. Many homes had a fireplace in each room and fireside accessories were plentiful. This coal box is fitted with a small hook at the back of the box to hold a brass scoop. To avoid using hinges, which can be fiddly and expensive, the lid just slots on to the front of the box.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature wooden coal box with a lid and a brass handle.

templates.name: Coal box side template
templates.shape_description: Trapezoidal shape with one long side angled and the opposite side possibly having a slight curve.

diagram_descriptions: A miniature wooden coal box with a hinged lid, a small brass handle on the lid, and a hook on the back.
Two identical trapezoidal pieces of light-colored wood, representing the sides of the coal box.
A rectangular piece of light-colored wood with one long edge chamfered at an angle.
Several small pieces of light-colored wood, including a cylindrical piece suitable for a drawer knob, and small blocks.
Two trapezoidal pieces of wood with a visible wood grain pattern, positioned as mirror images, representing the sides of the coal box with angled top edges.

projects.name: Coal Box

steps.instruction: Take the base wood piece and mark 1/8in from one short side edge. Position and glue the front support on the line so there is a 1/8in gap between the outside edge of the base and the front support.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular wooden piece with a smaller rectangular piece glued to one short edge, leaving a 1/8in gap.

steps.instruction: Position the base as shown. Place the two sides beside the base (ledges facing), together with the back wood piece and glue the three pieces on to the outside edges of the base.
steps.visual_description: The base piece with two side pieces and a back piece glued to its outer edges, forming an open box.

steps.instruction: Fix the brass handle centrally on to the top wood piece by inserting one 1/8in long brass pin into each hole at the side of the handle through into the wood. Glue the construction on top of the coal box.
steps.visual_description: A small brass handle attached to a wooden piece with brass pins. This piece is shown being glued on top of the assembled coal box.

steps.instruction: Take the front wood piece and position it so the chamfered edge faces forwards and downwards. Mark 1/8in from the front long edge and centrally position and glue the wooden knob into place. Once dry, check it slots into the front of the box.
steps.visual_description: A wooden knob is being glued to a wooden piece with a chamfered edge. This piece is intended to fit into the front of the coal box.

steps.instruction: To make the hook at the back of the box, cut an eye pin to measure 1/4in long and use pliers to slightly open the eye of the pin. Mark 1/8in down from the back of the coal box and drill a hole centrally using a 1/32in drill bit and glue the eye pin into place.
steps.visual_description: An eye pin is being prepared and then inserted into a hole drilled in the back of the coal box.

steps.instruction: To make the scoop, fold the brass sheet in half. Trim the side edges to a slight angle as shown. Make a hole in the top of the folded sheet using a 1/32in drill bit. Take the length of brass wire and secure the end into the hole using superglue gel. Once dry, curve the sides into the shape of a scoop.
steps.visual_description: A brass sheet is folded, trimmed, and a hole is drilled. A brass wire is inserted into the hole to form the handle of a scoop.

steps.instruction: To make the handle for the scoop, remove the straight end from the belaying pin using mitre cutters. Use a 1/32in drill bit and drill a hole into the flat end of the pin. Dab the end of the wire with superglue gel and insert it into the pin handle.
steps.visual_description: A belaying pin is cut and drilled. The wire handle of the scoop is inserted into the drilled end of the belaying pin.

steps.instruction: When the scoop is not in use, insert the brass rod into the hook at the back of the box. Traditionally, coal boxes were lined with metal but this is not included in this project. Instead, dry brush the inside with black acrylic paint and when dry, fill with coal.
steps.visual_description: The finished coal box with the scoop inserted into the hook. The inside of the box is shown filled with model coal.

tips: An alternative to the brass sheet used for the handle and coal scoop is the malleable metal of a tomato purée tube which is brass coloured on the inside of the tube. Model railway coal is ideal for filling the coal box.
projects.finished_product_description: A miniature wooden coal box with a brass handle and a scoop made from brass sheet and wire.

projects.name: Festive Silk Bows

steps.instruction: To make the bow maker, drill two 1/16in holes into the wooden block so they are in line with each other and 3/8in apart. Screw the hooks into the drilled holes with the openings facing the same way.
steps.visual_description: A piece of wood with two screw hooks inserted, openings facing the same direction.

steps.instruction: Take the silk ribbon and rest it in the openings of the hooks, leaving 2in at one end to work with and the excess at the other end. It doesn't matter how long the excess ribbon is, just work directly from the spool or length of ribbon to avoid wastage.
steps.visual_description: A piece of wood with two hooks, and a red ribbon threaded through the hooks, with ends extending.

steps.instruction: Cross the ribbon in front of the hooks by bringing the short end over the top of the excess ribbon, so each end changes sides.
steps.visual_description: The red ribbon is crossed in front of the hooks, with the ends switching positions.

steps.instruction: At this stage you will need a tool like the small pair of scissors shown. Hold the ribbon in one hand and scissors in the other.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a red ribbon and a pair of scissors.

tips: Depending on the width of the silk ribbon, you can vary the size of the hooks and the distance apart. For 2mm silk ribbon the hooks should be 1/4in apart. For 5mm silk and organdie ribbon they should be 1/2in apart. The same method can be used to make other delicate bows out of threads, string and raffia.
projects.finished_product_description: Tiny bows made from silk ribbon.

diagram_descriptions: Three small red silk bows arranged in a cluster.
A finished gold mesh bow with long trailing loops.
A small finished gold ribbon bow with short loops.
A simple bow shape made from a single strand of ribbon.

projects.name: Christmas Card Ribbon Decoration

steps.instruction: Use the point of the scissors to push the short end piece beneath, through the gap in the hooks and underneath the ribbon which is held in the hook openings.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of scissors pushing a red ribbon under two small gold hooks attached to a beige board.

steps.instruction: Hold the ribbon and gently pull each end, so each end is flat and vertical in front of you.
steps.visual_description: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through and hanging vertically from the front.

steps.instruction: Bring the short end piece of ribbon over the top of the ribbon held in the hooks and hold to your left-hand side whilst taking the opposite end to the right-hand side.
steps.visual_description: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through. One end is brought over the top of the other and held to the left, while the other end is held to the right.

steps.instruction: Ease the excess ribbon underneath the short end of silk ribbon to form a small loop and hold as shown above.
steps.visual_description: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through. A small loop has been formed on the front.

steps.instruction: Tuck the short end of the ribbon up and through the silk ribbon loop. Pull each end to centralize and tighten the knot in between the two hooks.
steps.visual_description: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks. The short end of the red ribbon is tucked through the loop and pulled to tighten a knot between the hooks.

steps.instruction: Slide the bow off the hooks and trim the ribbon ends to an angle and to the length required.
steps.visual_description: A finished red ribbon bow with angled ends, detached from the hooks.

tips: You could display Edwardian Christmas cards on a length of 3mm wide silk ribbon, topped with a bow. Christmas card catalogues contain tiny modern and antique images which may be used. Some are small enough to be used as they are, while others may need to be reduced on a photocopier.
projects.finished_product_description: A decorative bow made from red ribbon, attached to a card or other item using hooks.

diagram_descriptions: Step 5: Close-up of scissors pushing a red ribbon under two small gold hooks attached to a beige board.
Step 6: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through and hanging vertically from the front.
Step 7: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through. One end is brought over the top of the other and held to the left, while the other end is held to the right.
Step 8: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks, with a red ribbon threaded through. A small loop has been formed on the front.
Step 9: A piece of beige board with two gold hooks. The short end of the red ribbon is tucked through the loop and pulled to tighten a knot between the hooks.
Step 10: A finished red ribbon bow with angled ends, detached from the hooks.
Tip: A vertical arrangement of small Christmas cards and images, strung on red ribbon and topped with a red bow.

projects.name: Stocking and Presents

materials.item: Paper ribbon in a variety of colours

steps.instruction: Photocopy and cut out the stocking template on page 62. Place the template on top of a folded piece of red paper ribbon, creases running vertically, and cut to shape. Cut a 1in x 1/16in piece of red ribbon, loop it over and glue it to the top of one of the stocking pieces.
steps.visual_description: Two images showing a red paper stocking cut out from folded paper, and a finished red stocking with a white top.

steps.instruction: Glue the edges of the two stocking pieces together. Cut four 3/4in x 1/2in pieces of cream paper ribbon and glue on to each side of the stocking as shown. Once dry, trim to shape. Cut a 1 3/4in x 3/16in length of cream paper ribbon and glue around the top of the stocking.
steps.visual_description: Two images showing a red stocking with cream paper ribbon glued to the sides and top.

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of paper ribbon to fold around a small rectangular wooden block (creases to run with the longest length of the block) – the block size shown is 7/8in x 3/8in x 1/8in. Trim the sides to the height of the block and then glue the block on to the paper.
steps.visual_description: A green paper-wrapped block with a cream paper ribbon on top.

steps.instruction: Wrap the paper around the wood, using tacky glue to secure. Crease the side flaps, fold over and glue neatly on to the end of the block. Tie metallic thread around the wrapped parcel to provide the finishing touch.
steps.visual_description: Three images showing green paper-wrapped blocks, with one tied with metallic thread.

projects.finished_product_description: A handmade Christmas stocking and small wrapped presents.

projects.name: Paper Chains

steps.instruction: Take a strip of quilling paper and cut it into 5/8in lengths. Repeat with the remaining strips of paper. Wind a strip around the dowel to make the first ring and use a small amount of tacky glue to secure the end.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows a dowel with a strip of paper wound around it, forming a ring. A second strip is shown being wound around the dowel.

steps.instruction: Remove the ring from the dowel and thread a different coloured strip of paper into the ring. Rest the dowel next to the previous ring, wind the new strip around the dowel to make the second ring and glue to secure the end. Repeat using the remaining strips to create a long chain.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows a completed ring threaded onto a new strip of paper, with the dowel positioned next to it. A second ring is shown being formed around the dowel.

projects.finished_product_description: A long chain made of interlocking paper rings.

projects.name: Crackers

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of red paper ribbon 3/4in square and glue a short wood dowel piece centrally to the top of the paper (creases running horizontally). Place the forms on either side, roll the paper around all three wood pieces and glue to secure the end of the paper.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows a square piece of red paper with a short dowel glued to the top center. Two other dowels (forms) are placed on either side, and the paper is being rolled around them.

steps.instruction: Take a 2in length of wire and position between the dowel centre and a form. Using pliers, twist the wires to gather the paper. Trim off excess wire, remove the form and repeat on the opposite end. Glue a 1/2in x 3/16in piece of gold paper around the centre.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows a cracker form with wire twisted around the paper at one end. A piece of gold paper is shown being glued around the center.

tips: You can easily modernize the crackers by decorating them with tiny confetti shapes.
projects.finished_product_description: Christmas crackers made from red and gold paper ribbon.

diagram_descriptions: Image of several finished crackers, some decorated with stars.
Diagram showing the process of making paper chains, illustrating winding paper strips around dowels to form rings.
Diagram showing the process of making crackers, illustrating rolling paper around dowels and securing with wire.

projects.name: Garland

materials.item: Antique pine and light oak water-based wood stain

steps.instruction: Use wire cutters to cut a length of evergreen garland or pipe cleaner approximately 7in long. Bend into the shape shown in the photograph above.
steps.visual_description: A length of evergreen garland bent into a wavy shape.

steps.instruction: Take another length of evergreen and wind around the garland shape to thicken it. This may need to be repeated depending on the original thickness of the evergreen garland/pipe cleaners.
steps.visual_description: A second length of evergreen garland being wound around the first to thicken it.

steps.instruction: To make cinnamon sticks, take the centre cane and soak in warm water for a few minutes, then pull straight, weigh down each end and leave to dry. Stain with a mix of antique pine and light oak wood stain and once dry cut into 3/8in lengths.
steps.visual_description: A cane being soaked, then pulled straight and weighed down to dry, followed by stained pieces cut into short lengths.

steps.instruction: Take three cinnamon sticks and bundle together, winding wire around the centre to hold in place. Trim the end of the wire leaving 1/8in protruding for securing into the garland. Decorate the garland with the sticks, seeds, peppercorns, dried berries and bows.
steps.visual_description: Three cinnamon sticks bundled together with wire, and a close-up of various decorative elements like seeds and peppercorns.

tips: See instructions on page 54 for ribbon bows.
projects.finished_product_description: A festive garland made from evergreen branches, decorated with cinnamon sticks, berries, seeds, and bows.
